text:
Probably going to regret trying to continue this but the [good] syndicates / big players spend 80% of their time trying to not move the price so you need to think outside the box a little if you want to try and follow. I would disagree <@U016535QCJ2> as it really doesn’t take much money to move the market (assuming you have a good model in the first place) 

That’s not to say their isn’t an edge here as any modelling that looks to try and model ‘trading flow’ as it can be very valuable.

elements.text: Probably going to regret trying to continue this but the [good] syndicates / big players spend 80% of their time trying to not move the price so you need to think outside the box a little if you want to try and follow. I would disagree
as it really doesn’t take much money to move the market (assuming you have a good model in the first place)
That’s not to say their isn’t an edge here as any modelling that looks to try and model ‘trading flow’ as it can be very valuable.

root.text: If a price has moved then it's probably moved towards 0EV, so you'd have to consider whether whatever value was there before is now reduced or  perhaps eliminated. That doesn't mean you can't make this idea work though - it's worth researching any idea you might have because with sufficient effort there's a good chance that you'll either make it work or (more likely in this case) learn from the process and move towards something that does work.

elements.text: If a price has moved then it's probably moved towards 0EV, so you'd have to consider whether whatever value was there before is now reduced or  perhaps eliminated. text:
I think that confirms what I'm thinking. It's not a stupid idea, but the key would be to catch it before all the value's gone. In my head you'd be looking for a signal that says this price is likely to move, then wait a bit to confirm it and then bet on it before it stops moving, i.e. reaches 0EV.

The back tests I've done seem to suggest it's possible, the bets beat BSP, but whether it works in practice would be another matter.

text: I pretty much agree with the "80% of their time trying to not move the price" unless it's to pile on the money late (in which case they go for it).  So <@U4H19D1D2>, are you talking about UK racing pre-play? Or other markets? I think you need to be at least >5% of matched (going on at the time) to move a market, but if the availability of a selection is thin, and the market is fairly static, it probably wouldn't take much. I was talking more about UK horse racing pre-off in the last few minutes where a lot of players are putting their money into the market

elements.text: I pretty much agree with the "80% of their time trying to not move the price" unless it's to pile on the money late (in which case they go for it).  So

I was talking more about UK horse racing pre-off in the last few minutes where a lot of players are putting their money into the market

text: You could also consider whether a signal that the market is about to move might be more valuable if you just use it straight away rather than waiting for 'confirmation'. Knowing that a market is about to move is a proxy way of identifying +EV prices because the net of market movement is towards 0EV.

elements.text: You could also consider whether a signal that the market is about to move might be more valuable if you just use it straight away rather than waiting for 'confirmation'. Knowing that a market is about to move is a proxy way of identifying +EV prices because the net of market movement is towards 0EV.

text: Yes, but of course that's harder to do! What I'm thinking is, if the strategy I have actually works in practice, the next step would be to then refine it to identify the movements earlier to get more value. The problem I foresee with that is you're more likely to then get false positives.

elements.text: Yes, but of course that's harder to do! The problem I foresee with that is you're more likely to then get false positives.

text: I'm just saying consider it. If you're a new player the priority should probably just be to get something (anything really) written up and running so that you can learn.

text:
Oh yeah definitely - it is something I'm considering. I am new to this, I've got a couple of strategies that are working (not making loads, but not losing at least), but they use different methods for working out prices to bet at. 

As you say, I just need to get something working and then learn from that.

text: <@U016535QCJ2> would you say that generally these syndicates are taking volumes rather than offering prices? Or are they somewhere in the middle?

text: I think that would vary, but my client in the main just took what was there just before jump

text: Yeah, I would imagine if you’re not very price sensitive (ie. have a large margin in a fundamental model) then generally taking volume would enable you to match more. I expect they do both though.

text: <@U01QCEQD9MF> has joined the channel

Given the two following hypothetical scenarios, which would you consider to return the most profits long term, or indeed would the profits be approx the same :

Scenario 1: 1 Betfair Account running a proven strategy , £20 Liability Stakes
Scenario 2: 4 Betfair Accounts running the same strategy as above, £5 Liability Stakes

Assume all PC paying accounts and same comms etc
Just interested in opinions/thoughts and personal experience. Thanks

text: <@UQL0QDEKA> 1) is probably a bit better because you avoid situations where orders you would have matched get cancelled or matched by someone else in between orders sent by 2). If you are betting both sides then 2) will generate more commission so may help if you need to avoid 50% or 60% PC rates

text: You can't just assume that more money matching = better. There are plenty of reasons to believe thinner volumes to provide opportunities. Rather too much gets assumed in this game, it's better to check.
